key_insight: An end-to-end computational pipeline that converts a patient's tumor transcriptome into personalized de novo small-molecule candidates by combining transcriptome-derived target identification with metaheuristic molecule assembly and target-driven filtering.
problem_solved: Addresses the lack of personalized drug options for AML caused by extreme molecular heterogeneity by linking patient-specific gene-expression signatures to de novo drug generation and prioritization.
method: Patient-level transcriptome analysis (e.g., WGCNA and differential expression on TCGA-LAML) to identify dysregulated gene modules and candidate protein targets.

Metaheuristic assembly of de novo small molecules conditioned on selected targets and chemical constraints (e.g., genetic algorithms / simulated annealing to build chemically valid scaffolds optimized for multi-objective scores).
Target-driven filtering and prioritization using predicted binding (docking/scoring), ADMET and drug-likeness filters to produce ranked, personalized candidate compounds.
impact: Demonstrates how multi-omic profiling can be integrated with generative chemistry and multi-objective optimization, providing a reproducible blueprint for AI/ML practitioners building personalized drug-discovery pipelines and accelerating candidate prioritization.
visual_elements: End-to-end pipeline flowchart: transcriptome → target modules → metaheuristic molecular assembly → filtering → top candidates
Heatmap or network diagram showing patient-specific gene modules and prioritized targets
Illustration of metaheuristic molecule assembly (building blocks + fitness landscape optimization)
Funnel or stacked bar chart of filtering stages (initial pool → docking pass → ADMET pass → final ranked candidates)
paper_title: Transcriptome-Conditioned Personalized De Novo Drug Generation for AML Using Metaheuristic Assembly and Target-Driven Filtering
paper_authors: Abdullah G. Elafifi, Basma Mamdouh, Mariam Hanafy, Muhammed Alaa Eldin, Yosef Khaled
